item.title: CEOs are of the opinion that soft skills will be more important than hard skills in the future
item.description:
Asian CEOs view soft skills as more vital than hard skills for future business success, according to a report by The Economist Corporate Network (ECN), an advisory service for senior executives. The report highlights communication, structural support for skill development, and CEO time constraints as key challenges. The ECN’s “Skills 4.0: How CEOs Shape the Future of Work in Asia” report, based on a survey of over 500 clients, reveals that most CEOs acknowledge the impact of major global trends (“megatrends”) on their companies...

item.title: Finding good people is still a challenge, according to ManpowerGroup
item.description:
Source: ManpowerGroup infographic. Around the world, the most difficult positions to fill are in skilled trades (particularly chefs, bakers, butchers, mechanics, and electricians), sales, engineering (mechanical, electrical, and civil), technician roles, and drivers (especially heavy vehicle operators), according to workforce experts ManpowerGroup. The situation in Singapore is somewhat different. While engineers are among the top five hardest roles to fill, as elsewhere, the other four are accounting and finance professionals, sales representatives, secretaries (including receptionists and administrative assistants), and marketing, public relations, and communications specialists...

item.title: The skills you possess will be valuable in securing future employment opportunities
item.description:
Legrand illustrates how LinkedIn is innovating by connecting existing skills with the needs of emerging jobs. Olivier Legrand, Managing Director for Asia Pacific at LinkedIn, suggests that many individuals already possess some qualifications for in-demand jobs without realizing it. During his keynote, “Job titles are out, skill sets are in,” at the Singapore Computer Society’s Tech3 Forum, Legrand stated that LinkedIn aims to connect its members not only with employers but also with suitable companies, relevant jobs, and essential skills for future career prospects...

item.title: Singapore is dedicated to developing talent in the infocomm sector
item.description:
Singapore’s Minister for Communications and Information, Dr. Yaacob Ibrahim, addressed the rising demand for infocomm professionals in the country. This surge is attributed to the growth of the ICT sector and Singapore’s Smart Nation initiatives. Dr. Yaacob emphasized the need to fill 30,000 infocomm positions by 2020. He acknowledged the challenge of meeting this demand solely with local talent, stating that while relying on non-Singaporeans might be necessary, the focus should be on equipping Singaporeans with highly competitive skills...

item.title: IBM has raised concerns about the skills gap in India
item.description:
Source: IBM. Cover for the Upskilling India report. IBM has released a study conducted by the IBM Institute for Business Value (IBV), in partnership with the Economist Intelligence Unit.
